page.title: 19RELICS OF WORLD WAR II
page.content: During {World War II} the coast of East Anglia was vulnerable to enemy attack and, to guard against this possibility a variety of defences were erected. Evidence of this can been seen in our area. The remains of anti-invasion obstructions are under the sea in grid squares 53 88 and 53 89. They often foul the gear of longshore boats. On the cliff at 537 888 can be seen the concrete remains of the coastal defence battery of heavy guns installed during the war. At 536 874 are the concrete plinths of anti-aircraft gun mountings. At various places in the area can be seen concrete and brick pillboxes which served as machine gun and observation posts as well as large pre-formed concrete blocks which were used as anti-tank obstructions. The rifle range at 53 89 was constructed before the war.It is W.D. property and still used
